comments.text:
I need to amend my comments to the last two people. 

There are no limits to the level of compassion people can feel for other 
living beings, but there are limits to the resources and time which can be 
dedicated to compassionate acts. We have to pick our battles.

To decide that you will focus on animal rights and value animal life over 
human life is your choice. However, you are also depending on others to 
value your own life over animal life every time you enjoy that luxury. How? 
Every time you eat you are consuming food which is of higher quality than 
the food fed to livestock. You are eating from the highest quality land, 
which was taken away from grazing animals and hunting animals. You are 
living in an area which was probably populated by wild life of some sort 
before humans converted it. Just by living you necessarily put your own 
needs ahead of animals'. Your rights were put ahead of animals' rights at 
nearly every turn. And yet you have the temerity to stand up and demand 
that others' rights be ignored because of the idealism fostered by the 
lifestyle given to you. 

The people in those camps have to eat corn and cabbage gruel. They 
supplement their diets with rats, bugs, snakes and lizards. Are you going 
to be more upset about the animals they manage to poach? Seriously, if you 
are as committed as you claim to be, you should be. Those animals all have 
feelings. The prisoners are obviously not valuing their right to live. 
They're being selfish, aren't they? Or is it that they don't have the 
luxury to pass up a food source? I want you to think very deeply about 
this. They don't have the luxury to make the same decision you make every 
day when you eat your quinoa. 

Those who are starving don't have to worry about heart disease like we do. 
They don't have to make a choice between lentils and beef. They have to 
decide which child eats. So when you come at me, talking about how animals 
feel, I'm going to come back at you with how a mother feels when she has to 
decide which child will live. You have no idea what real suffering is 
because you've never faced the sort of suffering the third world faces 
every day through slavery, starvation, oppression, degradation, and general 
misery. This misery is actually the consequence of first world consumer 
demand. Yes, you're complicit, too. You're using technology to type this 
stuff up. That's almost always a product of slave labor. Almost all of our 
clothes were made by slaves. Unless you're buying second hand you're buying 
into these markets. There are more slaves now than ever before. And you 
are't bothered. You probably even consume slave-created products. The 
slaves of the world have created a utopia for you. And you stand up on 
their backs to say to hell with human suffering. Animals first. This is the 
height of hubris. Your'e like a spoiled crown prince who wants to hand feed 
his horses while the people starve. 

That's why I dismiss you with "first world problems." What you're saying, 
unwittingly, is let them eat cake.
comments.author: liz is

If you're concerned about saving the lives of the innocent people, staying 
away from armed intervention is probably your best bet. North Korea has a 
draft, and in such a scenario, virtually every young healthy male would be 
enlisted, and against a superpower like the US and the North Korean

least 60-70% of these young males would be brutally killed.

drone strikes in Pakistan and Yemen. It would just be chaos, and it would

You can say the US had something to gain when they intervened in all of 
these places, and that's true. Just like every nation on earth, the US 
places it's own interests first. However, the US does have a lot to gain by 
toppling the North and reuniting the peninsula. 

The one glaring benefit would be China losing it's only satellite 
state(China knows this and it's why they are willing to invest so much in 
the regime). A reunion of Korea under Southern leadership would be a huge 
boon to US interests in the region. China would completely surrounded by US 
allies(Japan, Taiwan, the new United Korea et cetera), thus blocking any 
future attempts by China to assert itself. The reasons the US can't 
intervene are obvious.

China has a seat on the UN Security counsel, and thus will veto any attempt 
to overthrow the regime. Plus, even though the North Korean Military is a 
joke, They still have artillery loaded with nuclear shells aimed at 
Seoul(the South Korean Capital). Any attack will result in Seoul being 
nuked. 

Invasion is currently impossible, even if we get China to support such a 
move. Internal revolution isn't likely. The biggest thing we can hope for 
is to stop China from sending aid to North Korea(it's largely the reason 
the regime is still able to function).

Even a covert operation to take out the "dear leader" would likely result 
in nuclear weapons being used on somebody. It's an impossible situation. ﻿

comments.text:
+HyrdaRancher Exactly. And the fact is that the major obstacle to green 
energy is the current conflict of interest that divides the people from the 
politician's masters -- the energy companies. There already exists 
technology that completely solves some of the long-distance travel in a way 
that doesn't consume any resources whatsoever -- magnetic trains. There's 
one in use in Japan already, and it's both the fastest train in the world 
as well as the most green one. The problem is that in the current economy, 
stuff like that are insanely expensive to produce and put into practice. 

We also have the opportunity to use solar energy to a degree which it's not 
today, which is a ridiculous waste. For example, many homes could become 
self-sufficient in energy by the use of well-designed and well-placed solar 
panels. There's even a case of a man in the US building solar panels 
himself from aluminum cans -- old soda cans -- painted with a certain kind 
of paint, and the energy he harvests from this device is enough to 
completely fuel his entire home. 

Not only is this less of a Gehenna to the planet, it is also cheaper 
long-term for both our society as well as our individuals. The cost 
barriers at the moment is in the Research and Development. For example, 
magnet trains could probably be streamlined into a cost-efficient stage 
within the next 30 years to the point where it could be affordable to a 
wider degree than it currently is -- but this is extremely unlikely without 
proper funding from both private investors as well as government, because 
both the research and the technology is insanely expensive right now -- 
just like all technology is at its genesis. 

There are solutions to the problem of finite resources in certain areas, 
the problem is that the market economy and its profit-based tunnel vision 
discourages sustainable -- i.e profitless -- energy and investments into 
it. This problem is only amplified the farther along the line of free reign 
for corporations you get.
comments.author: La Nausée

comments.text:
+godonlyknows13 It's gotten a bad rep by the same forces that have stolen 
the word "libertarianism". Historically, Libertarian Socialism is the 
antithesis to the authoritarian capitalist and the neoliberal society. But 
maintaining the status quo of having clear and well-defined structures of 
power and class divides, is paramount for both politicians and the rich to 
stay in control of society. In an anarchist society, there is no place for 
risk capitalists. Workers have no reason to sell their labour, in contrast 
to owning their own work.

This is incompatible with how society is currently run, especially with the 
current idea of democracy. American Democracy is the biggest lie in 
contemporary political discourse. America has no democracy, it's an 
oligarchy. The Republicans and the Democrats are essentially two factions 
of the same political party, and have the same financiers and masters. 
Third party candidates have no chance of winning the presidential election, 
or become representatives with actual power. Propaganda that steers public 
perception away from there being any alternatives to how society is run is 
paramount for this status quo to continue.

This is also why the CIA has toppled or attempted to topple many South 
American democracies with leftist economic policies and social safety nets. 
This is also why they've tried to assassinate Fidel Castro more times than 
I can count. Propaganda and force makes people think there's no alternative 
to how society is run -- but the problem with the status quo is that it 
demands infinite growth on a finite planet to work economically. But the 
fact is that the liberal psuedodemocratic consumerist society cannot 
survive long-term. 

The entire global economy is based entirely around the debt of countries 
where private banks and other profit giants reap the benefits. This is 
completely self-destructive for everyone in the long-term. The fact is that 
the US has dug itself into a hole that is so big that if the US publicly 
express explicitly that they are never going to repay their debts, then the 
entire global economy would collapse instantaneously. In other words, the 
exact same thing that happened to Greece would happen to every first world 
(and most second world) countries on the planet. On the other hand, it 
would sky rocket the growth of the third world, because the biggest 
obstacle to third world autonomy is western corporations for example forces 
farmers to sell their production to the west, by making sure that the 
locals can't afford to compete with their prices. This is also based around 
the debt economy, where the farmers essentially end up in a position where 
the only way they can continue to produce food is if they sell a fixed 
amount of the produce before even planting it. 

With this long-ish analysis, I think it should be self-evident why the 
established powers have shifted public perception into thinking things like 
anarchy, or a democracy without representatives overall, is chaos and 
disorder. It's also the biggest evidence of the representative politicians 
not working for the people, because of the conflict of interest whereby 
what's best for the workers is mutually exclusive with what's best for the 
politicians and their financiers.
